ABSTRACT The synthesis and application of a hydrotrope (phosphoric ester of glycerol; EFG) as a carbonate wettability modifier was investigated, and the results compared among commercials wettability modifiers ‚Äî dodecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (DTAB), sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) and lauryl alcohol ethoxylate phosphate ester ‚Äî which are recognized in the academic literature as wettability modifiers. Contact angle, spontaneous imbibition tests, adsorption in porous medias and reservoir core flooding tests were performed and the obtained results were analyzed. In this coreflood test, it was used reservoir Brazilian pre- salt rock and crude oil samples from a pre-salt reservoir . The reservoir pressure (6200 psi) and temperature (85 ¬∞C) were replicated , in this test the EFG shows a 9% reduction in residual oil saturation . In general, the res ults have shown that the hydrotrope can successfully increase carbonate rock hydrophilicity and, consequently, increase the oil recovery factor, without significant IFT reduction, which can cause the formation of stable emulsions during oil recovery. Napht henic acids (NA) dissolved in decane, mineral oil and original pre-salt crude oil were used as a model oils to render calcite surfaces oil -wet.
